results.title: Conservation tillage protecting our greatest asset
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Protecting Our Greatest Asset”.
It should be noted that this video is made by a chemical company that manufactures herbicides. Intensive cropping and continual cultivation stresses the Australian soil dramatically. This video looks at alternative methods to soil tillage by machinery, namely herbicides. Crops which require no tillage as conservation are also discussed.

results.title: Tomatoes for processing
results.creator_credit: Jack Keane, Rod Kefford, Ann Millard and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description:
Film begins with instructions on how to garner and prepare tomato seeds for planting, before focusing on the seed germination process and how to cultivate a good crop of seedlings.

The seedlings are then uprooted and planted in larger fields. Manual and semi-automatic seedling planting techniques are shown using different types of machinery.

When fully grown the tomatoes are picked and packed into wooden crates. Film details the correct picking and packing process.

Finally, the tomatoes are taken to a factory, where they are pulped and made into tomato sauce.

Good colour/shoits throughout.

results.title: Catch of the day
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission, Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Sarah Watt
results.brief_description: The bright, beautiful and spontaneous ocean is something to wallow in. A young girl plays in the ocean and with the fishes. A dashing surfer rides up on his white steed and declares ‘I’ve come - you’ll never have to chop onions again!’ Jane wakes up from her dream (or was it a nightmare?) Working at the fish market, she endures the sexual innuendo and double entendres from male customers and fellow workers alike. When matters come to a head, she cleverly takes the situation into her own hands and offers a unique solution to unsolicited sexual advances… An impressionistic animation.

results.title: In the shadow of Hollywood [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Sylvie Groulx, Eric Michel and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: With its barrage of special effects, its new heroes and warrior myths, the American dream is not what it used to be. Aided by new trade strategies, Hollywood is tightening its stranglehold on the world’s screens, leaving no room for indigenous cultures. Disturbed by this one-sided war of images, the director consults filmmakers and other experts on both sides of the Atlantic. Agnieszka Holland, Arthur Penn, Alain Tanner, Bertrand Tavernier, Milos Forman and Denys Arcand ponder the fate of cinema in the era of globalization. Can auteur cinema with its personal vision, its expression of the collective identity, withstand the onslaught of American movies and their single-minded focus on entertainment? Includes interviews with Denys Arcand, Anne-Marie Bidaud, Luciana Castellina, Milos Forman, Claude Fournier, Agnieszka Holland, Marin Karmitz, Todd McCarthy, Jonathan Nossiter, Arthur Penn, Leslie Quinton, Roland Smith, Jean-Charles Tacchella, Alain Tanner, Bertrand Tavernier, Daniel Toscan du Plantier, Margarethe Von Trotta, Andrzej Wajda and Irwin Winkler. In English and French with English subtitles.

results.title: Panorama: the state wide screen [excerpts No. 1]
results.brief_description: Excerpts from the Panorama documentary on the State Film Centre of Victoria. Candid footage of the goings on at the S.F.C.V. in Carlton in the early sixties. Customer service, despatch operations, film retrieving, checking and cleaning, and free film screenings in urban and rural areas.

results.title: A Feeling of self worth
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Vandalism Task Force and Robin Young
results.brief_description: A feeling of self worth describes the approach taken at Monterey and the positive impact this has had on the school. Present and former staff and the parents of former students talk about the school as it used to be and the improvements that have been made.

results.title: Tasmania's south west: a wilderness in question
results.creator_credit: Damon Smith, Rolf De Heer and AFTRS

video_links.name: Tasmania's south west: a wilderness in question

results.brief_description: Designed to increase public awareness of the nature of the South West Tasmanian wilderness and the threats facing it. Concentrates on the two main threats, namely the Hydro-Electric Commission’s damming and flooding of the wild rivers of the area for power development purposes and the extensive logging of the native forests by the Forestry Commission. Explores the issues at hand by interviews with leading figures on both sides of the struggle. Narrated by Ian McGarrity.

results.title: How AI sees me
results.brief_description: All those videogame and anime-inspired avatars you’re seeing on social media aren’t as innocent as they look. After uploading selfies and paying a small fee, the Lansa app can turn users into fairy princesses and rugged adventurers. But the AI-generated artworks are trained on the work of actual artists, some of whom fear their creativity will be replaced by computers. Non-White users have also reported that the app anglicised their features, while at other times it’s created sexualised images from pictures of children. Not to mention some believe that users are paying to train facial recognition intelligence and give up their personal data. So, look before you Lansa.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Red Desert Render
results.brief_description:
The world of Rockstar Game’s Red Dead Redemption 2 is meticulously crafted. Not only are its environments rendered in stunning detail, but it’s designed to keep players interested and engaged. Like a theme park, it has waypoints, landmarks, maps – design features that encourage the player to explore the game and its narrative without feeling lost.
By contrast, award-winning game designer, Ian MacLarty describes the vast expanses that exist out of bounds as feeling transgressive, surprising and impermanent – a piece of genuine digital wilderness, where the landscape responds unpredictably to player action. One wrong move could risk the player respawning within the map’s bounds and spending hours trying to break out again.
This was the experience MacLarty tried to replicate in Red Desert Render, a surreal open-world game that encourages curiosity and surprise. Its auto-generated landscapes are intentionally unstable – entering the ‘shop’ changes the shape of your avatar drastically, and swimming in a bath propels you into the sky, where you can swim through the air.
It represents a couple of turning points in MacLarty’s artistic practice: it’s his first open-world videogame and his first multiplayer online game. MacLarty has continued to refine the design principles we see in this work in the videogames he has made since, including his upcoming release Mars First Logistics.

group_siblings.title: The Grannies
group_siblings.creator_credit: Luke Neher, Marie Foulston and Nick Murray
group_siblings.credit_line:
Music by Sam Gill and Luke Neher. Sound design by Sam Gill. Starring Kalonica Quigley, Andrew Brophy, Marigold Bartlett, Ian MacLarty, and friends. Voiceover is excerpted from an interview originally for P3 Spel, conducted by Angelica Norgren.

Visuals captured from Red Dead Redemption 2
Rockstar Games, USA, 2018

Courtesy Marie Foulston
